title: So "Lore Update" means throwing away champions?
body:
Well title says it all. 

Varus' new lore is good written and all but how has it anything to do with the old champion that people loved? That is not Varus anymore, that is a story for a completly new, generic demon dude. You should _update_ the lore not throw away the old champ and replace it with something new that no one asked for.

replies.body: I suppose this is their way of making people relevant to their new world. As I feared, they would continue worse.
I wish someone could explain how new varus lore makes him more relevant than his old one.

> [{quoted}](name=Foucz,realm=EUNE,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=z1dTsaQ6,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2017-11-30T16:29:39.262+0000)
>
> I wish someone could explain how new varus lore makes him more relevant than his old one.

On the most superficial level, he went from being corrupted by an unrelated, ambiguous magical force to being corrupted by a darkin. He's now part of an ongoing conflict that involves multiple champions and regions. The choices he makes are no longer just about himself + the Noxians that killed his loved one, but also the future of the darkin race in Runeterra. 

I wouldn't go so far as to call him "irrelevant" before, but he's definitely a more connected and central character now.

I know y'all are getting quite some negative feedback, but thanks to y'all for getting some LGBT+ representation in there!

I like Varus' new place a lot, and I am excited to see what happens going forward.

{{champion:44}} nuf said.
Varus was sacrificed for NOTHING.

Hell, ANYONE whose story wasn't built around their goddamn WIFE AND CHILD would've made a much better candidate for being revealed as gay. Riot literally took the worst choice of a character, and threw their entire background away so they can fit. Oh well - yet another character fallen before the "we need a token [insert minority] character, but instead of making a new one or a sensible change to an old one we'll just ruin someone who was already well established and lowed" storywriting cancer agenda.

I disagree.

Varus's story wasn't about him having a wife and child. Him being in a heterosexual relationship wasn't core to his character **AT ALL**.

What was important, was that he gave into a dark force because his loved ones had been killed and he was desperate. Vengeance is also still a major theme.

The gender of his lover didn't "ruin" his lore.

> [{quoted}](name=Arakadia,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=z1dTsaQ6,comment-id=0000000000020004000000010002,timestamp=2017-12-01T00:39:23.844+0000)

>

No the core of his story was that ALL he had left was vengeance, to the point that he willingly let himself be consumed. Now the vengeance is barely even a part of the hosts (at least by the end of the comic) instead the vengeance belongs almost solely to the Darkin, who seems to not even be in control most of the time, instead this being about the quest of these two lovers to be freed from this curse that is the Darkin. The vengeance is now an afterthought, something they do their best to keep in check, which strikes me as extremely different from the tragedy of the old Varus.

> [{quoted}](name=Xenos von Faneli,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=z1dTsaQ6,comment-id=00000000000200040000000100020001,timestamp=2017-12-01T02:27:25.357+0000)
>
> No the core of his story was that ALL he had left was vengeance, to the point that he willingly let himself be consumed. Now the vengeance is barely even a part of the hosts (at least by the end of the comic) instead the vengeance belongs almost solely to the Darkin, who seems to not even be in control most of the time, instead this being about the quest of these two lovers to be freed from this curse that is the Darkin. The vengeance is now an afterthought, something they do their best to keep in check, which strikes me as extremely different from the tragedy of the old Varus.

I think what you've said here (and in reply to Arakadia's comment) is extremely insightful.

Was Varus' story more about a wife and child? Or a loved one? 
Was it more about the tension between family and duty? Or the tension between principles and desperation? 
Was he defined more by having nothing left but vengeance, and his "fall" when being willingly transformed into an instrument of darker purpose? Or was it the deep emotional trauma (realized or threatened) that drove him choose a "deal with the devil" in the first place? 

There's no right answer here. Players (and Rioters) saw (and still see) different parts of Varus' identity as the most primary. Some players absolutely hate what we changed because we changed the primary thing they loved - and you know what? We get it. We're not gonna try to tell you you're wrong, because you aren't. 

But some players really love what we changed, because they think (as we thought) it reinforced and evolved the primary thing they loved about Varus. 

We are reading through literally all of your comments, and we'll reply where we can, but I really want to stress this - you're all going to have different feelings about this, and we're ok with that.

If we’re going to be this divisive over a champion, why change them at all? You could’ve introduced lovers fused into one being as a new champion. You could’ve done a vgu that at least better justifies changing a champion’s story.

If you’re going to repeatedly retcon characters that create divisions within the community, why should we bother following the story? I’m trying hard to support the retcons, to even say that some are better, but I don’t blame people for being fed up with their favorite champions being rewritten so severely.

> If we’re going to be this divisive over a champion, why change them at all?

Because then literally no champion would ever change? You can't add to someone without 'changing' them remember.


> If you’re going to repeatedly retcon characters that create divisions within the community, why should we bother following the story?

...Because you like the character? As DyQuill said- some like the new lore- some hate it. Neither side is "right". 
Question- how important were Varus' wife and child in his old lore? Theoretically central sure, how much text was given to describe them? What was their hair colors? Their hobbies? 

Just curious. Because if they're barely described- then they're not important. They're important as a device- not people. And the device can change.

They could’ve given more background on his family the way they did to the lovers. No one has said the lore shouldn’t expand, but it’s how severely it’s been changed that’s the issue.

It’s like DC retconning Cyborg into never being a Teen Titan.

> [{quoted}](name=JacctheInsomniac,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=z1dTsaQ6,comment-id=0000000000020004000000010002000100000002,timestamp=2017-12-01T02:59:25.231+0000)
>
> Actually, you _are _ going to tell us we're wrong. That's what you've done by erasing his lore. You've told us that what we loved about Varus is wrong, and what you decided was more important is right.
> 
> Of course you're ok with us having "different feelings." It's easy to be okay with us having "different feelings," because ultimately you reign supreme no matter what we say or do.

Jacc, I'm gonna be real with you. 

I read your essay, and i can feel your frustration, your outright anger. I get that for you, we basically killed your champ. Erased the thing you loved like it was nothing, just because we could. That's a terrible fucking feeling, and for that specifically, I want to apologize. 

You're right - we do ultimately "reign supreme." That crown lies heavy, though, it really does. It keeps us up at night, and I'm not exaggerating. 

We feel we have a responsibility to you and every player. This is your game, your characters as much - no, more so - than it's ours. 

But there are so, so many of you. So many that we have a responsibility to, and for so many things: to keep the game and lore interesting. To stay true to what you love about it, while evolving and updating it. To build a world millions can lose themselves in, but still find a corner of it that speaks to them - specifically them. 

I want to apologize because it's clear we erased that corner of your world today. And I won't try to justify it. 

We did do what we thought was important. We made a decision, in full consideration of the responsibility we have to you and every player, and we stand by that decision. 

But that decision is one you have every right to hate.

>But there are so, so many of you. So many that we have a responsibility to, and for so many things: to keep the game and lore interesting. To stay true to what you love about it, while evolving and updating it. To build a world millions can lose themselves in, but still find a corner of it that speaks to them - specifically them.

So who does this actually appeal to? Because from what I've seen the reaction to this change has been overwhelmingly negative. There was actually no reason to make this change, it's just change for the sake of change and all that ever accomplishes is pissing off people who liked the old way better.

As for the diversity point, you could change 70% of League's champions to be gay and it wouldn't impact their story at all. So why Varus, one of the very few champions who's sexuality was interwoven into his original story? It feels forced, heavy handed and flat out wrong.

> [{quoted}](name=LankPants,realm=OCE,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=z1dTsaQ6,comment-id=000000000002000400000001000200010000000200000002,timestamp=2017-12-01T03:26:07.854+0000)

> As for the diversity point, you could change 70% of League's champions to be gay and it wouldn't impact their story at all. So why Varus, one of the very few champions who's sexuality was interwoven into his original story? It feels forced, heavy handed and flat out wrong.

Boards has been pretty negative, so I get where you're seeing that. Reddit on the other hand has been less so. And on Twitter, we got a ton of positive support. But even within those, there are differences - some positive comments on Boards, and some negative ones on Twitter, and so on. 

The channel/forum is ultimately irrelevant. It's about players overall, and we've seen players all over have every reaction, from super pissed to overjoyed. We're still sorting through it and getting a sense of how we did, but I'm pretty confident that this "actually appeals" to a good amount of players. 

I guess what I'm saying is - echo chambers are real (not just Boards, but reddit and Twitter and everywhere), and there are more than a few players that are excited about these changes, just as there's a good number here that are very much the opposite.

Just a friendly reminder that Twitter is boarderline the largest echo chamber of them all with it being over run with specific goals and support (and reports of the company controlling what people see). I would also like to wonder and ask how many people who are supporting on Twitter are actual players of the game, or just people who heard there was now a gay character and are just throwing their support to you. 

I have always hated changing of any character ever for the sole purpose of change. This is honestly the cowards way of being progressive. Instead of letting a gay character be made and stand on its own, you took a character that has been popular for some time and changed him gay when he was standing fineish on his own (i say ish incase there was anything in the old lore that people may have thought needed changing). BOLD would be making a gay character straight up and letting the community support it and purchase him/her and show support by playing the character. This is just an attempt at being supportive of a community in the weakest way possible.

He lost everything that defined his worldview. He lost the reason he cared and stayed to defend Pallas in the first place.

I would upvote this twice if I could.

Old Varus was about losing *everything*.  His story was about doing the right thing, and then having life kick you in the gut for it.  It was a story about a broken man who was going to go out in a blaze of vengeance, consumed like the wick of a candle.  And really, I think that would have been okay.  I think it would have been great if Varus' story ended.  If the power the thing from the pit gave him allowed him to blow a hole through the Noxian lines and allow their beach-head to be thrown back into the sea.

And then?

Then he dies.

He dies knowing that he prevented countless other fathers from having to mourn the loss of their own sons and daughters.  He would have died knowing he made a difference.

Technically not, but you missed his argument. New 'Varus' (if I could call them that) isn't about much vengeance because both of the men are still alive. One of them didn't die, they live on together. Where's the motivation for vengeance?

Why is the 'dark force' just a soulless killer and not even the slightest interesting?

I know you're kidding or whatever, but the state of being trans is a very personal and real thing to some people and Zyra certainly is not trans.

LGBT representation in LoL and video games in general has been getting better but there is room to make improvement.
Yea but why do you need representation

Being part of a minority often comes with feelings of loneliness, or in some cases (and certainly with being transgender feelings of active aggression) toward who you are as a person, literally for just existing and being who you are.

Seeing representation in media (not just video games, of course) can provide a sense of kinship (ah, there are other out there who feel what I feel!) and seeing those sorts of struggles depicted also makes you think "hey, there is someone else out there feeling/understanding the struggles that I go through!"

These are just a few reasons, but representation is important to different people for different reasons.

I'm not transgender myself, but I am a minorty, and I understand what it can be like to see good representation in media.

Another recent example of this would be Wonder Woman, who provides a positive, competent role model for young women in a world where men are dominant, often to the point of absurdity.

It's almost like most people don't want annoying politics or things that make the game worse. I don't want established characters getting turned gay for no actual purpose other than the fact that Riot can do it. Therapists exist for a reason, don't rely on video games and ruin it for everyone else.

This isn't about politics. It's about people and their very personal feelings about themselves.

And Riot did not make Kai and Valmar gay because of some political initiative (though I want to be clear, Riot is trying very hard to be a progressive and inclusive company)

They were just telling a story about two character who happened to be gay. Riot was not making a political statement here and if they were I'm not sure what it would have been.

Sorry your sjw comments get so downvoted, I’m sure that’s discouraging. I get where you’re coming from on this. The issue is that nobody would downvote a post about adding gay champs but changing them is apparently the issue. That being said the trend of ending objectification of women for instance is unpopular regardless because we all want our escape. We want a virtual world with obscenely busty and hallow women at our beck and call. The rest of the world isn’t like that so games are a final bastion of sexiness. I’ve also gotta double down on zyra. Jokes aside she did gain a gender and therefore is transsexual in a way. Malphite may qualify along with Maokai as well. Someday people may identify as trees honestly so it isn’t that far fetched the way things are going.

I'm certainly not discouraged; these sorts of comments can be found anywhere on the internet. I can be downvoted a thousand times, my beliefs and resolve are unaffected.

I want to be clear: I don't think they should have changed that aspect of Varus. If they wanted to bring in a gay champion, they could have easily made a new one, or modified an older champion who was more ambiguous.

What I am saying is that if this change is going to happen, we might as well find a silver lining, and while I am regretful for what we've lost for Varus, I do enjoy his new lore. Quite a bit.

As for objectified women: go wild. They can be everywhere as long as there is balance, and I think league is getting there on that.

Also, gaining a gender from gaining _sentience_ doesn't make you transgender.

Not gonna lie, it's tough out here. Discussion on Boards can be super brutal, and not because of the criticism (that we totally want and deserve, because we are making stories with characters all of you super care about), but because when we try to give some insight, it feels like it's taken as an opening statement in a debate.

I feel like Varus being a parent was a huge part of what shaped him to be what he was. You can't just take away defining characteristics and expect people to love the new version of that certain character. Varus is probably the worst offender but it has also happened to champions like Galio (always joking around, we never get serious characters anymore? Or at least no serious VO) and Lux where you removed the "Spellthief" part of her being able to copy spells from other mages. 

Also want to mention Lux's new voice was a downgrade (yes there was more lines but quality>quantity) where they show very little of her struggle of being a mage in a society where they are not accepted and instead sounds like she is saying something Lulu or Zoe would say.

> You can't just take away defining characteristics

Just curious, how was Varus being a parent one of his defining characteristics? When I think of defining traits I think of really crucial elements that the character wouldn't be themselves without. So, for a character like Ana from Overwatch, I can totally see why being a parent is crucial to her character. It's written all over her backstory and dialogue. But In Varus' old story, his family was hardly mentioned -- we don't even know whether he had a wife or a husband, just that he had a child, who was brought up in passing. This just seems like a plot device that was used to drive Varus' story arc, not a defining characteristic.

So really, the core of what drove Varus to his lust for vengeance was not the loss of a particular wife or child, but the loss of _family_ -- which can mean different things to different people. Better yet, if what appealed to you about Varus' previous lore was the tragedy of his lost loved ones, this still exists in his new lore -- Val and Kai can't return to their families in Ionia until the Darkin within them is destroyed (there's a scene in the comic about this). One might say this is even more tragic than having Varus' family killed by Noxians because, if and when Val and Kai ever finally defeat the Darkin, their families might already be long dead.

"Perhaps he would not find his broken wife alongside his broken boy"

"Showing Theshan where to hold the bow, how to draw, and how to remember his breath gave Varus a better understanding of these things himself. His son would need to know these things for himself; his father had been anointed Temple Guardian, after all"

Those are quotes from his League Judgement which were canon.

I think the old Varus lore where he goes in the pit after defending it for most of his life is a lot more tragic than Val and Kai. Varus had to choose to protect the pit or protect his family and when they died he did what he was has been trying to prevent his life and went in to the corruption. Val and Kai at least have each other and it seems like it will probably be a "love wins" cliche.

I already saw the video but I’m still unsure why you decided to go for a homosexual love.

Then, given that Kai and Val were both damaged goods from their battle with the Noxians, we can assume the Darkin understood that neither of their weakened, and dying bodies could survive with him in them, so he merged them into a singular, healthy individual he could escape in.
Why is it that you describe it as homosexual love and not just love?
Because I feel like I’d be ignoring the elephant in the room.
